name: Maria Pichler
text: I sold my gaming PC, all of my podcast recording equipment, deleted all of my shows, and promised to not play any games or watch TV until I got a job. Here's how I made key sacrifices, found a community, hunted for a job, and finally landed one. After working at IBM and MedSpoke, I now work on web development for Amazon.

name: Julian Wagner
text: I was lucky enough to join a company that offered a lot of autonomy and a web development class for anyone, not just IT folks. So I was encouraged to become a developer after I expressed my interest to my manager. It was just a start and I decided to take the Code Factory Frontend course and now I work for Pinterest.

name: Anna Moser
text: I started learning some programming in the '80s, '90s, and early 2000s. I ended up going to grad school twice before I moved from hardware engineering to programming. I've found that the paths that people take to get into programming are much more varied than stereotypes give credit for, and I think it's useful to see that. Today I run a startup ranked #7 in Europe.

name: Dario Weber
text: I worked in the culinary industry for many years before realising I wanted a career change.I remembered my teenager hobby of modifying web pages in the notepad editor and decided to start by doing the cheapest web design jobs on Craigslist, until I finally took the Code Factory Backend course and now, 6 months after I work for Facebook.
